questions.stem: The 'Dodo bird verdict' in psychotherapy outcome research refers to the finding that:

options.text: Cognitive-behavioral therapy consistently outperforms all other therapies across all disorders
All bona fide psychotherapies produce roughly equivalent outcomes when compared directly
Psychotherapy is no more effective than placebo for most psychological disorders
Brief therapies are consistently more effective than long-term therapies

questions.explanation: The Dodo bird verdict (from Alice in Wonderland: 'Everybody has won, and all must have prizes') refers to the controversial finding that different bona fide psychotherapies produce roughly equivalent outcomes. First suggested by Rosenzweig (1936) and empirically supported by Luborsky et al. (1975), this finding is interpreted by common factors proponents (e.g., Wampold) as evidence that shared therapeutic ingredients drive change rather than specific techniques.

questions.stem: According to Lambert's model of therapeutic outcome variance, which factor accounts for the LARGEST proportion of therapy outcome?

options.text: Specific therapy techniques (approximately 15%)
Therapeutic relationship (approximately 30%)
Extratherapeutic factors such as client variables and life events (approximately 40%)
Expectancy/placebo effects (approximately 15%)

questions.explanation: Lambert's model estimates that extratherapeutic factors (client variables, social support, life events, fortuitous occurrences) account for approximately 40% of outcome variance — the single largest contributor. The therapeutic relationship accounts for approximately 30%, while expectancy/placebo and specific techniques each contribute approximately 15%. This model supports the common factors perspective that elements outside therapy itself are the primary drivers of change.

questions.stem: Howard and colleagues' dose-response research found that approximately what percentage of therapy clients showed measurable improvement by session 8?
questions.explanation: Howard et al. (1986) found a negatively accelerating (log-linear) dose-response relationship: approximately 50% improved by session 8, 75% by session 26, and 85% by session 52. The curve shows diminishing returns — the largest gains occur earliest in treatment. This finding has significant implications for managed care and session limits, supporting the value of brief interventions while recognizing that some clients require longer treatment.

questions.stem: The distinction between efficacy and effectiveness in psychotherapy research primarily concerns:

options.text: Whether the study uses quantitative versus qualitative methods
Whether the treatment was tested under controlled research conditions versus real-world clinical practice
Whether the study measures symptoms versus overall functioning
Whether the therapist uses a manualized versus flexible treatment approach

questions.explanation: Efficacy studies test treatments under ideal, controlled conditions (RCTs with manualized treatments, homogeneous samples, trained therapists) and have high internal validity. Effectiveness studies examine outcomes in real-world clinical practice with diverse patients and routine conditions, having high external validity (generalizability). This distinction is fundamental to evaluating the evidence base and understanding how research findings translate to clinical practice.

questions.stem: The APA's definition of evidence-based practice in psychology (EBPP) integrates three components. Which of the following is NOT one of these components?

options.text: Best available research evidence
Clinical expertise
Randomized controlled trial results exclusively
Patient characteristics, culture, and preferences

questions.explanation: EBPP integrates three components: (1) best available research evidence (not limited to RCTs — also includes case studies, qualitative research, and clinical observation), (2) clinical expertise, and (3) patient characteristics, culture, and preferences. The EBP framework was developed partly in response to criticisms that the EST movement overemphasized RCTs. EBPP explicitly values multiple forms of evidence, not RCT results exclusively.

questions.stem: Which of the following are correctly identified as criticisms of the Empirically Supported Treatment (EST) movement? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Overemphasis on manualized treatments at the expense of clinical flexibility
Potential exclusion of effective treatments that lack research funding, such as psychodynamic and humanistic therapies
Undervaluing the role of the therapeutic relationship and common factors
The EST criteria are too lenient and allow treatments without adequate evidence to be designated as empirically supported
Treating disorders as discrete entities when comorbidity is the norm in clinical practice

questions.explanation: Major criticisms of the EST movement include overemphasis on manuals, exclusion of under-researched but potentially effective therapies, undervaluing the therapeutic relationship and common factors, and treating disorders as discrete when comorbidity is common. The EST criteria (Chambless criteria) are actually criticized for being too stringent, not too lenient — requiring multiple RCTs from independent research groups, which advantages well-funded research programs.

questions.stem: Which of the following findings from the Smith and Glass (1977) meta-analysis are accurately reported? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The average effect size across all therapies was approximately d = 0.85, a large effect
The average therapy client was better off than approximately 80% of untreated controls
Different types of therapy produced broadly similar effect sizes
Psychotherapy was found to be no more effective than placebo
Behavioral therapies were found to be dramatically superior to all other orientations

questions.explanation: Smith and Glass (1977) conducted the first meta-analysis of psychotherapy outcomes, combining 375 studies. They found an average effect size of d = 0.85 (large), meaning the average therapy client outperformed 80% of untreated controls. Different therapy types produced broadly similar effects, supporting the Dodo bird verdict. Psychotherapy was clearly effective compared to no treatment, and no single orientation dramatically outperformed others.

questions.stem: According to psychotherapy outcome research, which of the following are accurately described as common factors shared across effective therapies? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The therapeutic alliance — a collaborative, trusting relationship between therapist and client
Client expectancy — the client's hope and belief that therapy will help
Systematic desensitization — gradual exposure to feared stimuli paired with relaxation
Therapist empathy, warmth, and positive regard
Cognitive restructuring — identifying and challenging irrational beliefs

questions.explanation: Common factors are therapeutic ingredients shared across all effective therapies: therapeutic alliance, client expectancy/hope, therapist empathy and warmth, and other relational factors. Systematic desensitization is a specific behavioral technique, and cognitive restructuring is a specific CBT technique — both are technique-specific factors rather than common factors. The common factors model (Wampold, Lambert) argues these shared elements account for more outcome variance than specific techniques.

questions.stem: Which of the following correctly describe Howard's phase model of psychotherapy outcome? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Remoralization — restoration of hope and subjective well-being — occurs earliest in treatment
Remediation — reduction of specific symptoms — follows remoralization
Rehabilitation — improvement in overall functioning and life patterns — occurs latest
The three phases always occur in strict sequential order with no overlap
Symptom reduction typically occurs before the restoration of hope

questions.explanation: Howard's phase model proposes three sequential phases: (1) Remoralization (restoration of hope, earliest), (2) Remediation (symptom reduction), and (3) Rehabilitation (improved overall functioning, latest). The phases are sequential but overlapping — they are not rigidly separated. Importantly, hope (remoralization) typically precedes symptom reduction (remediation), not the reverse, which has implications for understanding early therapy progress.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about therapist effects in psychotherapy outcome research are accurate? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Therapist effects account for approximately 5-9% of outcome variance, comparable to or larger than the effect of specific techniques
More effective therapists tend to have strong facilitative interpersonal skills including empathy and warmth
Years of clinical experience is the strongest predictor of therapist effectiveness
There is significant variability in outcomes across therapists even when delivering the same manualized treatment
Therapist effects are negligible when treatment manuals are strictly followed

questions.explanation: Research consistently shows therapist effects account for 5-9% of outcome variance — comparable to or greater than specific technique effects. Effective therapists demonstrate strong interpersonal skills, alliance-building ability, and flexibility. Importantly, years of experience alone is NOT a strong predictor of effectiveness — deliberate practice and facilitative interpersonal skills matter more. Therapist variability persists even with manualized treatments, indicating that the therapist, not just the manual, matters.

questions.stem: Match each key finding or concept to the researcher(s) most closely associated with it.

rows.text: Dodo bird verdict — first empirical support

questions.explanation: Smith and Glass (1977) conducted the landmark first meta-analysis, finding d = 0.85. Luborsky et al. (1975) provided the first empirical support for the Dodo bird verdict through comparative outcome reviews. Howard et al. (1986) discovered the dose-response relationship (50% improved by session 8, 75% by session 26). Lambert developed the widely cited model attributing outcome to extratherapeutic factors (40%), relationship (30%), expectancy (15%), and technique (15%).

questions.stem: Match each evidence-based treatment to the disorder for which it has the STRONGEST empirical support as a well-established EST.
questions.explanation: ERP is the gold-standard treatment for OCD (strongest specific-treatment evidence). IPT was originally developed for and has its strongest evidence base in major depression (Klerman & Weissman). Prolonged Exposure (Foa) is a well-established treatment for PTSD. CBT (particularly including behavioral components like food diaries and exposure to avoided foods) is well-established for bulimia nervosa. These pairings represent some of the clearest examples where specific treatments outperform generic therapy.

questions.stem: For each research design characteristic, select ALL that correctly apply to efficacy studies, effectiveness studies, or both.
questions.explanation: Random assignment and manualized protocols are hallmarks of efficacy studies (RCTs), which prioritize internal validity and causal inference. Heterogeneous samples with comorbidities characterize effectiveness studies, which reflect real-world clinical practice. High external validity (generalizability) is the strength of effectiveness studies, as they test treatments under conditions that mirror typical clinical settings. Efficacy studies sacrifice external validity for internal validity, and vice versa.

questions.stem: For each therapy outcome concept, select ALL descriptions that correctly apply.

columns.text: Researchers tend to find superior results for their preferred therapy orientation
Approximately 5-10% of adult clients get worse during therapy
A negatively accelerating curve where the largest gains occur earliest in treatment
Therapeutic ingredients shared across all effective therapies

questions.explanation: The allegiance effect refers to the tendency for researchers to find superior results for their preferred orientation — when allegiance is controlled, differences between therapies shrink. The deterioration effect indicates that approximately 5-10% of adult clients (and 14-24% of child clients) worsen during treatment. The dose-response relationship shows a negatively accelerating curve with diminishing returns per additional session. Common factors are therapeutic ingredients (alliance, empathy, expectancy) shared across all effective therapies.

Cohen's d conventions: 0.2 = small, 0.5 = medium, 0.8 = large. The psychotherapy effect size of 0.85 is large and comparable to many medical interventions.

questions.explanation: Extratherapeutic factors (client variables, social support, life events) account for ~40% of outcome variance in Lambert's model. The dose-response curve shows 50% improved by session 8, 75% by session 26, and 85% by session 52. The Chambless criteria (Dianne Chambless) established the EST designation standards. questions.stem: A psychologist reviews the outcome data for a community mental health clinic and discovers that while most clients improve, approximately 8% of adult clients have actually deteriorated during treatment. Several of these deteriorating clients are seeing the same therapist, who has the highest caseload and reports feeling burned out. Analyze the clinical and research implications.

options.text: Therapist effects — significant variability in outcomes across therapists, with some therapists producing worse outcomes
The deterioration rate (8%) is consistent with research showing approximately 5-10% of adult clients worsen during therapy
The deterioration is entirely due to clients' pre-existing conditions and has nothing to do with the therapist
An 8% deterioration rate proves that psychotherapy is harmful and should be discontinued at this clinic
The need for routine outcome monitoring and early warning systems to identify deteriorating clients and underperforming therapists
The Dodo bird verdict — all therapists produce equivalent outcomes regardless of skill
The need to eliminate all psychotherapy and replace it with medication management
Implement Lambert's OQ-45 or similar progress monitoring system to track client outcomes session-by-session and flag deterioration early
Provide the struggling therapist with supervision, support, and reduced caseload to address burnout
Ignore the deterioration data because some clients are expected to get worse regardless of treatment quality
Immediately terminate the therapist without further assessment or support

questions.explanation: Research shows 5-10% of adult therapy clients deteriorate, and therapist effects account for 5-9% of outcome variance — some therapists consistently produce worse outcomes. The clustering of deterioration cases with one burned-out therapist suggests therapist factors are contributing. Lambert developed the OQ-45 early warning system specifically to address deterioration by tracking progress session-by-session. Appropriate responses include implementing outcome monitoring and providing therapist support, not ignoring the data or terminating without assessment.

questions.stem: A clinical researcher finds that in a comparative outcome trial, CBT and psychodynamic therapy produced equivalent outcomes for depression (both d = 0.75 compared to wait-list control). However, the CBT researcher designed the study, trained the therapists, and developed the treatment manual. The psychodynamic therapy was delivered by therapists recruited from the community with minimal additional training. Analyze the methodological implications.

options.text: The allegiance effect — the researcher's preference for CBT may have influenced study design, therapist training, and implementation in favor of CBT
Unequal implementation — CBT received more favorable conditions (specialized training, manualization) than the comparison therapy
The equal outcomes prove that CBT and psychodynamic therapy are identical treatments
The psychodynamic therapy results are invalid because community therapists cannot deliver effective treatment
Researcher allegiance and implementation differences can confound comparative outcome research and must be controlled
The study definitively proves the Dodo bird verdict with no methodological concerns
RCTs are fundamentally flawed and should never be used in psychotherapy research
Future studies should control for allegiance by using researchers equally invested in both treatments or including allegiance as a variable
Both treatments should receive equivalent training, supervision, and implementation support to ensure a fair comparison
Only the researcher's preferred treatment should be tested in future studies to avoid confounds
Community therapists should never participate in RCTs because they introduce too much variability

questions.explanation: The allegiance effect is a well-documented phenomenon in which researchers tend to find superior results for their preferred therapy. In this case, CBT received more favorable implementation conditions (specialized training, manualized protocol) compared to psychodynamic therapy, creating an uneven comparison. Despite these advantages for CBT, equivalent outcomes emerged — which could be interpreted as actually favoring psychodynamic therapy. Future research should control for allegiance and ensure equivalent implementation conditions.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe findings or concepts from psychotherapy outcome research.
questions.passage: Psychotherapy outcome research has established several robust findings over decades. [The overall effect of psychotherapy compared to no treatment yields a large effect size (d = 0.80-0.85), meaning the average therapy client is better off than approximately 80% of untreated controls]. Researchers have debated whether specific techniques or common factors drive change, and [Lambert's model estimates that specific techniques account for only about 15% of outcome variance, while extratherapeutic factors account for approximately 40%]. Howard's dose-response research showed that [the relationship between number of sessions and improvement follows a positively accelerating curve, with the largest gains occurring in the final sessions of treatment]. Research on therapist effects has demonstrated that [there is no meaningful variability between therapists — when using the same treatment manual, all therapists produce equivalent outcomes]. The Chambless criteria established two levels of empirical support, and [examples of well-established ESTs include CBT for depression, ERP for OCD, and prolonged exposure for PTSD]. Furthermore, [approximately 5-10% of adult therapy clients deteriorate during treatment, highlighting the importance of outcome monitoring].

highlightableSegments.text: The overall effect of psychotherapy compared to no treatment yields a large effect size (d = 0.80-0.85), meaning the average therapy client is better off than approximately 80% of untreated controls
Lambert's model estimates that specific techniques account for only about 15% of outcome variance, while extratherapeutic factors account for approximately 40%
the relationship between number of sessions and improvement follows a positively accelerating curve, with the largest gains occurring in the final sessions of treatment
there is no meaningful variability between therapists — when using the same treatment manual, all therapists produce equivalent outcomes
examples of well-established ESTs include CBT for depression, ERP for OCD, and prolonged exposure for PTSD
approximately 5-10% of adult therapy clients deteriorate during treatment, highlighting the importance of outcome monitoring

questions.explanation: Therapy yields a large effect (d = 0.80-0.85, better than 80% of controls) — correct. Lambert's model attributes 15% to techniques and 40% to extratherapeutic factors — correct. The dose-response curve is NEGATIVELY accelerating (largest gains earliest, diminishing returns), not positively accelerating — incorrect. There IS significant therapist variability even with manuals (5-9% of variance) — incorrect. CBT for depression, ERP for OCD, and PE for PTSD are well-established ESTs — correct. Approximately 5-10% of adults deteriorate — correct.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the evidence-based practice framework and related concepts.
questions.passage: The evidence-based practice (EBP) framework was developed in response to limitations of the EST movement. [EBP integrates best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient characteristics, culture, and preferences]. The framework recognizes that [multiple forms of evidence are valuable, including but not limited to RCTs — systematic case studies, qualitative research, and clinical observation also contribute to the evidence base]. Regarding the common factors debate, [Wampold found that specific treatment techniques account for at most 1-8% of outcome variance, while common factors account for substantially more]. Some critics argue that [the Dodo bird verdict means that training in specific therapeutic techniques is unnecessary since all approaches are equivalent regardless of therapist skill]. Research on deterioration shows that [Lambert developed the OQ-45 early warning system to track client progress and alert therapists when clients are deteriorating, enabling mid-course corrections]. Additionally, [the EST criteria (Chambless criteria) require that a treatment demonstrate superiority over a wait-list control in a single unreplicated study to be designated well-established].

highlightableSegments.text: EBP integrates best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient characteristics, culture, and preferences
multiple forms of evidence are valuable, including but not limited to RCTs — systematic case studies, qualitative research, and clinical observation also contribute to the evidence base
Wampold found that specific treatment techniques account for at most 1-8% of outcome variance, while common factors account for substantially more
the Dodo bird verdict means that training in specific therapeutic techniques is unnecessary since all approaches are equivalent regardless of therapist skill
Lambert developed the OQ-45 early warning system to track client progress and alert therapists when clients are deteriorating, enabling mid-course corrections
the EST criteria (Chambless criteria) require that a treatment demonstrate superiority over a wait-list control in a single unreplicated study to be designated well-established

questions.explanation: EBP integrates research, clinical expertise, and patient preferences — correct. Multiple evidence forms are valued in EBP, not just RCTs — correct. Wampold's findings attribute 1-8% to specific techniques — correct. The Dodo bird verdict does NOT mean training is unnecessary — therapist skill matters significantly, and some treatments do outperform others for specific disorders — incorrect. Lambert's OQ-45 tracks progress to catch deterioration — correct. The Chambless criteria require at LEAST two good experiments by DIFFERENT research teams showing superiority to placebo or equivalence to established treatment, not a single study — incorrect.

questions.stem: Arrange Howard's three phases of psychotherapy outcome in the correct sequential order, from the phase that occurs EARLIEST to the phase that occurs LATEST in treatment.

items.text: Rehabilitation — improvement in overall functioning, life patterns, and interpersonal effectiveness
Remoralization — restoration of hope, subjective well-being, and a sense that things can improve
Remediation — reduction of specific symptoms such as depression, anxiety, or behavioral problems
Stabilization — maintaining gains and preventing relapse through ongoing support
Integration — incorporating therapeutic insights into daily life and identity
Generalization — extending treatment gains to new situations and contexts

questions.explanation: Howard's phase model proposes three sequential phases of therapeutic improvement: (1) Remoralization — the earliest phase, involving restoration of hope and subjective well-being; (2) Remediation — reduction of specific symptoms; (3) Rehabilitation — the latest phase, involving improvement in overall functioning and life patterns. This model has important clinical implications: if a client's hope is not restored early, symptom reduction and functional improvement are unlikely to follow. Stabilization, integration, and generalization are reasonable extensions but not part of Howard's original model.

questions.stem: Arrange the following levels of evidence from MOST rigorous (strongest evidence for causal inference) to LEAST rigorous, as typically ranked in evidence-based practice hierarchies.

items.text: Systematic review / meta-analysis of multiple RCTs
Individual randomized controlled trial (RCT)
Quasi-experimental study (controlled but without random assignment)
Uncontrolled pre-post study (no comparison group)
Systematic case study with standardized measures
Expert opinion / clinical anecdote without systematic data

questions.explanation: Evidence hierarchies rank study designs by their ability to support causal inferences: (1) Systematic reviews/meta-analyses synthesize multiple RCTs for the strongest evidence; (2) Individual RCTs use random assignment for internal validity; (3) Quasi-experimental designs have control groups but lack randomization; (4) Uncontrolled pre-post studies lack comparison groups; (5) Case studies provide detailed individual data; (6) Expert opinion lacks systematic empirical support. EBP recognizes all levels contribute valuable information, but stronger designs are prioritized for causal claims.

questions.stem: A researcher replicates Howard's dose-response study, tracking the percentage of clients showing clinically significant improvement at different points during therapy. Two groups are compared: clients with acute adjustment problems and clients with chronic personality disorders.
questions.question: Which conclusion is BEST supported by the data?

options.text: Clients with acute problems show a faster dose-response pattern (earlier improvement) while chronic conditions require substantially more sessions, supporting differential dose-response curves by severity
Both groups show identical dose-response patterns regardless of diagnosis
Clients with chronic personality disorders do not benefit from psychotherapy at any dose
The acute group's improvement plateau at session 16 means therapy should be terminated at that point for all clients

questions.explanation: The data show differential dose-response curves: acute adjustment problems follow a steep negatively accelerating curve (55% improved by session 8, consistent with Howard's findings), while chronic personality disorders show a slower, more gradual improvement trajectory (only 15% by session 8 but 52% by session 52). This supports the clinical principle that severity and chronicity moderate the dose-response relationship, with more complex conditions requiring substantially longer treatment. The personality disorder group IS benefiting — just more slowly.

questions.stem: A clinic implements Lambert's OQ-45 outcome monitoring system. The graph shows symptom severity scores for two clients over the course of therapy (lower scores indicate improvement).
questions.question: Based on the OQ-45 data, which clinical action is MOST appropriate for Client B?

options.text: The therapist should receive a clinical support tool alert and modify the treatment approach, as the client's scores indicate deterioration
Continue the current treatment unchanged because fluctuation in scores is normal and expected
Immediately terminate therapy because the client is clearly not benefiting
Increase the frequency of sessions without changing the treatment approach

questions.explanation: Client B shows a clear deterioration pattern — scores are increasing (worsening) from 83 to 95 over 16 sessions. Lambert's OQ-45 system flags such clients as 'not-on-track' and provides clinical support tools to alert the therapist. Research shows that when therapists receive these alerts and modify their approach (e.g., changing techniques, addressing the alliance, seeking consultation), deterioration can be reversed. Simply continuing unchanged, terminating abruptly, or increasing frequency without conceptual change are inadequate responses.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept according to whether it represents a common factor (shared across therapies), a specific factor (unique to a particular orientation), or a research methodology concept.

items.text: Therapeutic alliance — collaborative bond between therapist and client
Systematic desensitization — graduated exposure paired with relaxation
Allegiance effect — researchers finding superior results for their preferred therapy
Client expectancy — hope and belief that therapy will help
Transference interpretation — analyzing the client's projections onto the therapist
Effect size (Cohen's d) — standardized measure of treatment impact

questions.explanation: Common factors are shared across all effective therapies: therapeutic alliance and client expectancy/hope are the most well-established. Specific factors are unique to particular orientations: systematic desensitization (behavioral) and transference interpretation (psychodynamic). Research methodology concepts include the allegiance effect (a methodological confound) and effect size (a statistical measure). The common factors vs. specific factors debate is central to understanding psychotherapy outcome research.

questions.stem: Categorize each feature according to whether it characterizes the EST (Empirically Supported Treatment) approach or the EBP (Evidence-Based Practice) approach.

items.text: Focuses on specific treatments for specific disorders using Chambless criteria
Integrates research evidence with clinical expertise and patient preferences
Values multiple forms of evidence beyond RCTs, including case studies and clinical observation
Prioritizes RCTs as the gold standard for establishing treatment efficacy
Recognizes that research should inform clinical practice
Explicitly incorporates patient culture and values into treatment decisions

questions.explanation: The EST approach focuses on specific treatment-disorder pairings using Chambless criteria and prioritizes RCTs (top-down: research dictates practice). The EBP approach integrates research with clinical expertise and patient preferences, values multiple evidence forms, and explicitly incorporates cultural factors (integrative). Both share the fundamental recognition that research should inform practice. EBP was developed partly in response to EST limitations, representing a broader, more clinically responsive framework.
